> [ssdifnskdjfnsdjk](#comment_1_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS): wget --mirror --convert-links --adjust-extension --page-requisites--no-parent --wait=1 http://example.org
> Explanation of the various flags:
> --mirror – Makes (among other things) the download recursive.
> --convert-links – convert all the links (also to stuff like CSS stylesheets) to relative, so it will be suitable for offline viewing.
> --adjust-extension – Adds suitable extensions to filenames (html or css) depending on their content-type.
> --page-requisites – Download things like CSS style-sheets and images required to properly display the page offline.
> --no-parent – When recursing do not ascend to the parent directory. It useful for restricting the download to only a portion of the site.
> --wait=1 – Wait the specified number of seconds between the retrievals of particular web elements/files.
> Maybe better solution than wget to mirror a site for offline or zeronet use is http://www.httrack.com

Do any of these (wget, httrack etc) optimize a site for 0net? Or are there compatibility problems between the mirror and 0net?
